awd_titl_txt: Career: Fundamental Studies of Sustainable Wireless Communication System Powered by Renewable Energy
awd_abstract_narration:
Wireless communications powered by renewable energy sources have been emerging as a promising solution to mitigate the carbon footprints to achieve a green radio network. However, renewable energy sources, such as solar and wind, are by nature unstable in their availability and capacity, which poses new challenges in the design and deployment of a sustainable communication network. The project will develop theoretical tools, propose new protocols and cross-layer optimization methods to enable an energy sustainable communication network. The multidisciplinary project will also foster the integration of research and education and provide both undergraduate and graduate students, particularly women and minority students, with an opportunity to participate in various training projects, which further inspire students to pursue high quality research with critical thinking. 

In a renewable energy powered communication network, the fundamental design criterion and main performance metric have shifted from energy efficiency to energy sustainability, i.e., to ensure the harvested energy can sustain the user demands with satisfactory quality of service provisioning. In this project, a novel performance metric, the energy sustainability, is first formulated, based on which the energy sustainable performance of a communication system will be systematically analyzed, characterizing the dynamic energy charging and discharging processes. The analysis will be leveraged to investigate a series of fundamental research issues on sustainable communication and networking, including energy management, network deployment, admission control, adaptive resource allocation, and medium access control. Analytical tools in queueing theory, game theory, stochastic optimization, probability theory, and random processes will be used in the design, analysis, and optimization of the proposed algorithms and protocols to ensure energy sustainable operation of a wireless communication network. The research outcomes of the project have potential to be implemented in the next generation wireless communication network powered by renewable energy.

por.por_cntn:
This project has contributed a fundamental study on energy sustainable wireless communication and networking. The project involves both theoretical analysis and practical protocol design and optimization to provide a comprehensive solution for the development and deployment of self-powered communications for 5G and beyond. The outcomes include a generic framework for energy sustainability analysis and sustainable capacity planning, protocol design and optimization for a fully energy sustainable wireless network, distributed WiFi charging, data driven optimization for distributed wireless networks with energy harvesting, and optimal power control and non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA) for massive IoTs with energy harvesting. Specifically, the research findings from this project have advanced the state of art of energy sustainable wireless communication and networking in the following aspects.

 1)      A generic framework is developed to analyze the energy sustainability of a wireless system with energy harvesting, characterizing the dynamic energy charging and discharging processes. Efficient resource management schemes are proposed to provide quality of service and ensure desirable energy sustainability performance of the network while achieving high resource utilization. The energy sustainable network capacity is further investigated under different network settings in terms of the densities of wireless devices, the stochastical wireless fading channels, diverse charging capabilities of wireless devices, with and without the use of data buffer or the energy buffer.

2)      We study practical protocol design and optimization for a fully energy sustainable wireless networks with both green energy and radio frequency energy transfer. Specifically, a joint beamforming design for concurrent energy harvesting and data delivery in a centralized wireless network is proposed to strike a tradeoff between the energy harvesting and throughput performance. In a cooperative network, the power and time are jointly optimized to attain the maximum sustainable network throughput. Lyapunov optimization is applied in an online stochastic resource allocation algorithm to achieve close-to-optimal network capacity.

3)      We contribute the first generic analytical framework for distributed Wi-Fi charging that accurately characterizes asynchronous energy charging and data delivery in a Wi-Fi network. Based on the analysis, the necessary and sufficient conditions are derived to ensure long-term energy sustainability of Wi-Fi devices. Efficient algorithms are proposed to adaptively turn the charging period of Wi-Fi devices to minimize the charging delay while ensuring the energy sustainability of Wi-Fi devices, based on diverse charging capabilities and traffic loads of devices.

4)      Data driven random access optimization for distributed wireless networks with energy harvesting is investigated. We formulate a joint problem of topology control and distributed random access as a constrained Markov Decision Process (CMDP) to attain the maximum network capacity under the energy sustainability constraints. A centralized model-based algorithm and a distributed model free constrained deep reinforcement learning (CDRL) algorithm based on Lagrangian primal-dual policy optimization is developed to solve the CMDP. The convergence of the proposed algorithms to the optimal solution is further established based on convex optimization and game-theoretic analysis.

5)      The optimal power control and non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA) for massive IoTs with energy harvesting is studied. A novel generic formulation of NOMA transmissions in an IoT network with random access is developed. The optimal power control design to ensure the maximum number of IoT devices involved in a successful concurrent NOMA transmission is proposed, and the upper bound of the NOMA transmission rate is derived. Novel CDRL algorithms have been developed based on two MDP models, i.e., a Partially observed MDP(POMDP) for known CSI, and a Hidden-mode MDP (HMMDP) for unknown CSI, to attain the optimal network performance in terms of the maximum sum rates, the maximum geometric mean of data rates, and the max-min date rates.

This project seamlessly integrates research and education in the areas of optimization, queuing theory, game theory, stochastic geometry, probability and random processes, machine learning, and wireless communication and networking. The multidisciplinary project provided many training projects to both undergraduate and graduate students, particularly women and minority students, at Illinois Institute of Technology, the students from Brazil, France, and Spain through IIT exchange programs. This project has inspired students to pursue high quality research with critical thinking.

The outcomes from this project have been published in top-tier conference proceedings and journals, disseminated to research communities through seminars in both academia and industry; and incorporated into course lectures and major project design for both undergraduate and graduate students. This project has trained students in the wireless communication and networking area and well prepares them for the future career in industry and academia. Two recently graduated PhD students involved in this project have joined the research labs in the leading networking companies.
